Irregular satellite ref_discovery=ref name="Discoverers_JPL"Discovery Circumstances [http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/?sat_discovery (JPL)] name=Kiviuq - Saturn XXIV discoverer=[[Brett J. Gladman|B. J. Gladman]] et al. discovery_date=in 2000 epoch=2000 Feb. 26.00 ref_orb_elems=ref name="JPL_mean_elems" Mean orbital parameters [http://ssd.jpl.nasa.gov/?sat_elem from JPL] semimajor=11.111 eccentricity=0.3288 inclination=45.71 period=449.22 d
(1.23 [[Julian year (astronomy)|yr]]) diameter=16 kmref name="Sheppard"[http://www.ifa.hawaii.edu/~sheppard/satellites/satsatdata.html Scott Sheppard pages] albedo=0.04 ref name="Sheppard" ''assumed'' color=''light red'' B-V=0.87
R-V=0.66ref name="Grav2003"[[Tommy Grav|Grav, T.]]; [[Matthew J. Holman|Holman, M. J.]]; Gladman, B. J.; [[Kaare Aksnes|Aksnes, K.]]; [http://arxiv.org/abs/astro-ph/0301016 ''Photometric survey of the irregular satellites''], Icarus, '''166''' (2003), pp. 33-45/0.48ref name="Grav2006"Grav, T.; and [[James Bauer|Bauer, J.]]; [http://arxiv.org/abs/astro-ph/0611590 ''A deeper look at the colors of Saturnian irregular satellites''] spectral_type=[[D-type asteroid|D]] ref name="Grav2006" '''Kiviuq''' (pron-enˈkiːvi.oʊk respellKEEvee-ohk or IPA-enˈkɪvi.ʊk respellKIVee-ook) is a [[prograde]] [[irregular satellite|irregular]] [[natural satellite|satellite]] of [[Saturn]]. It was discovered by [[Brett J. Gladman]] in 2000, and given the temporary designation '''S/2000 S 5'''.ref[http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/07500/07521.html IAUC 7521: ''S/2000 S 5, S/2000 S 6''] November 18, 2000 (discovery)ref[http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/mpec/K00/K00Y14.html MPEC 2000-Y14: ''S/2000 S 3, S/2000 S 4, S/2000 S 5, S/2000 S 6, S/2000 S 10''] December 19, 2000 (discovery and ephemeris) It was named in 2003 after a "giant" of [[Inuit mythology]].ref[http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iauc/08100/08177.html IAUC 8177: ''Satellites of Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus''] August 8, 2003 (naming the moon) [[Kiviuq]] (also spelled Keeveeok, Qiviuq or Kivioq) is a legendary and heroic Inuk, a sort of Inuit [[Odysseus]]. He has lived very long (or has had several lives), has wandered and journeyed, living all sorts of adventures whose details depend on the story-teller's local tradition. Kiviuq is about 16 kilometres in diameter, and orbits Saturn at an average distance of 11.1 million kilometers in 450 days. It is a member of the [[Saturn's Inuit group of satellites|Inuit group]] of irregular satellites. Kiviuq displays ''light-red'' colours and the [[infrared]] spectrum very similar to [[Siarnaq (moon)|Siarnaq]] and [[Paaliaq (moon)|Paaliaq]], further supporting the thesis of a possible common origin of the Inuit group in the break-up of a larger bodyref name="Grav2006"ref name="Gladman2001"Gladman, B. J.; [[Philip D. Nicholson|Nicholson, P. D.]]; [[Joseph A. Burns|Burns, J. A.]]; [[John J. Kavelaars|Kavelaars, J. J.]]; [[Brian G. Marsden|Marsden, B. G.]]; Holman, M. J.; Grav, T.; [[Carl W. Hergenrother|Hergenrother, C. W.]]; [[Jean-Marc Petit|Petit, J.-M.]]; [[Robert A. Jacobson|Jacobson, R. A.]]; and [[William J. Gray|Gray, W. J.]]; [http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/v412/n6843/abs/412163a0.html ''Discovery of 12 satellites of Saturn exhibiting orbital clustering''], Nature, '''412''' (July 12. 2001), pp. 163–166. Kiviuq is believed to be in [[Kozai resonance]] i.e. cyclically reducing the [[orbital inclination]] while increasing the [[orbital eccentricity|eccentricity]] and ''vice versa''.ref name="Cuk2004"[[Matija Ćuk|Ćuk, M.]]; and Burns, J. A.; [http://arxiv.org/abs/astro-ph/0408119 ''On the Secular Behavior of Irregular Satellites''], The Astronomical Journal, Vol. 128 (2004), pp. 2518-2541 == References == reflist *Ephemeris [http://cfa-www.harvard.edu/iau/NatSats/NaturalSatellites.html from IAU-MPC NSES] ==External links== *[http://www.ifa.hawaii.edu/~jewitt/irregulars.html David Jewitt pages]
